filedesc.updatestmt:
May 2014
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of the following works related to Blake’s development of his illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave : Preliminary Sketches for Robert Blair’s The Grave , listed under Drawings and Paintings, Pencil Sketches; Preliminary Drawings for Robert Blair’s The Grave , listed under Drawings and Paintings, Monochrome Wash Drawings; and Preliminary Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave , listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
In addition, we are republishing the following works, previously presented in our Preview mode, to make their designs fully searchable: Robert Blair, The Grave , the 1808 book listed under Commercial Book Illustrations, Designed by Blake and Engraved by Other Engravers; Deaths Door , listed under Separate Plates and Plates in Series, Designed and Engraved by Blake; and Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave , the series of twenty finished designs, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
Taken together, these works in a variety of media present a comprehensive overview of one of Blake’s major projects as an illustrator and exemplify his working methods as he developed rough sketches into finished water colors. The evolution of any one design can be traced via links presented under Related Works in the Archive on the pull-down menus, lower left on the main viewing page for each work.
In October 1805, Blake was commissioned by the engraver and would-be publisher Robert H. Cromek to prepare forty drawings illustrating Robert Blair's The Grave , a popular "Graveyard" school poem first published in 1743. Cromek originally planned to select twenty of these designs for a deluxe edition of the poem. Blake launched into the project with great enthusiasm, rapidly sketching out his illustrations in pencil, developing some into wash drawings, and then producing a group of more finished water colors for presentation to Cromek. In a first prospectus of November 1805, Cromek names Blake as both the designer and engraver of fifteen designs. Blake etched one image, Deaths Door , in white-line, but Cromek rejected it. The dark power of the print appeals to modern tastes, but was far from fashionable in the early nineteenth century. In a second prospectus, also of November 1805, Cromek announced that Louis Schiavonetti would engrave twelve designs for the new edition. Blake had lost the potentially lucrative commission to engrave his own designs; his relationship with Cromek descended into anger and argument. In spite of their disagreement, Cromek included a portrait of Blake as a frontispiece to the volume, published in 1808. Cromek promoted the book aggressively and the illustrations to The Grave became Blake's best known work through much of the nineteenth century.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
November 2006
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of Blake's water color illustrations for Robert Blair's The Grave . These are probably the twenty designs selected in 1805 by R. H. Cromek for publication in his forthcoming edition of The Grave , although only twelve were engraved by Louis Schiavonetti for the volume, published in 1808. One design, The Widow Embracing her Husband's Grave , has been known for many years, but the other nineteen water colors disappeared between their auction in 1836 and their dramatic rediscovery in 2001. These nineteen were sold individually at auction in spring 2006 and are now widely dispersed. The Grave water colors are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program). They join Schiavonetti's engravings and Blake's white-line etching of one design, "Deaths Door," previously published in the Archive.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Library of Congress, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries, museums, and private collectors that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 15.0 x 11.9 cm. and 33.2 x 29.7 cm.
objinfo.note: Objects 1-3, 5, 7, 10-13, 15-17, 20 have a vertical format; Objects 2-4, 6, 8-9, 14, 18-19 have a horizontal format.
objinfo.leafsize: ranging between 15.0 x 11.9 cm and 33.2 x 29.7 cm.
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water colors over traces of pencil
objinfo.note: The watermark appears in Objects 8, possibly 9, 11, 16, and 17. The watermark in Object 17 shows traces of an illegible date, possibly 1801.

There are framing lines on the mounts of Objects 2-20, but not on the sheets of paper bearing the designs. The mounts measure 33.0 x 26.5 cm.; two mounts show watermarks with an 1800 date. This early watermark makes it possible that the publisher, Robert Cromek, had the drawings mounted shortly after acquiring them from Blake and displayed them in this form to potential subscribers to his forthcoming edition of *The Grave* .

Formerly (c. 1821-2006) housed, unbound, in a red morocco wallet-style portfolio lined with red glazed paper showing a Beilby & Knotts 1821 watermark. This portfolio was sold at Sotheby's New York, 2 May 2006, lot 20 ($5040 to the dealer John Windle, who in turn sold the portfolio to a California private collector in July 2006).

provenance.name: Alan Parker, London (Objects 2, 5), Yale Center for British Art (Object 4), Marburg Ltd. (Objects 6, 7, 11), Louvre Museum (Object 8), Robert N. Essick (Objects 13, 14), Winterstein Collection (Object 17), H. Charles and Jessie Price (Object 18), private owners (Objects 1, 3, 9, 10, 12, 15, 16, 19, 20).

provenance.price: various, as indicated for each object in the note on provenance, below
provenance.note: Commissioned from Blake by Robert H. Cromek in the fall of 1805 (Cromek probably paid £21 for the group of twenty finished designs); Thomas Sivright of Edinburgh; sold from Sivright's collection, C. B. Tait auction, Edinburgh, 10 Feb. 1836, lot 1835, described as a "Volume of Drawings by Blake, Illustrative of Blair's Grave" and "entitled," apparently on a label no longer extant, "Black Spirits and White, Blue Spirits and Grey" (£1.1s., possibly to John Stannard or a dealer acting for him); John Stannard of Bedford; his son, Henry John Stannard, possibly by inheritance in 1882; his son, Henry John Sylvester Stannard, possibly by inheritance in 1920; his son, Henry Lawrence Stannard, possibly by inheritance in 1951; his nephew, a Glasgow resident, possibly by inheritance in 2000; sold in 2000 or 2001 to Caledonia Books, Glasgow, Object 4 no longer part of the group; the group of nineteen designs (Objects 1-3, 5-20) acquired jointly in 2001 from Caledonia Books by Paul Williams of Fine Books, Ilkley, West Yorkshire, and Jeffrey Bates of Bates & Hindmarsh, Leeds (£1000); Marburg Ltd. (the London dealer Libby Howie acting as agent) by Dec. 2002 (reportedly about £4.9 million); offered individually at Sotheby's New York, 2 May 2006, in nineteen lots as follows: lot 1, Object 1 ($744,000 to a private collector); lot 2, Object 17 ($576,000 to Hinrich Sieveking acting for the Winterstein Collection, Munich); lot 3, Object 8 ($1,584,000 to the Louvre Museum, Paris); lot 4, Object 18 ($912,000 to H. Charles and Jessie Price, Dallas, Texas); lot 5, Object 7 (not sold); lot 6, Object 15 ($1,024,000 to a private collector); lot 7, Object 9 (not sold; sold June 2006 to a private collector); lot 8, Object 11 (not sold); lot 9, Object 12 (not sold; sold June 2006 to a private collector); lot 10, Object 16 (not sold; sold June 2006 to a private collector); lot 11, Object 20 ($632,000 to a private collector); lot 12, Object 3 (not sold; sold no later than June 2008 to a private collector); lot 13, Object 6 (not sold); lot 14, Object 14 (not sold; sold June 2008 to Robert N. Essick); lot 15, Object 19 ($329,600 to a private collector); lot 16, object 13 ($329,600 to the dealer John Windle acting for Robert N. Essick); lot 17, Object 10 ($318,400 to a private collector); lot 18, Object 2 ($329,600 to Alan Parker, London); lot 19, Object 5 ($318,400 to Alan Parker, London). Object 4 was originally part of this group of designs, as the style and size of the backing mount indicate, but became detached from the other 19 designs at an unknown time, possibly by the mid-nineteenth century. This may be the design sold from the stock of the dealer Joseph Hogarth, Southgate and Barrett auction, London, 7 June 1854, lot 237, described as "Children at the Grave of their Parent" (with 5 others, 11s. to H. Palser). The later history of Object 4 is as follows: J. F. Hall by 1876; the dealer Carfax & Co., London; Mrs. Louisa Bishop, nee Salaman, by 1912; her son, Euston Bishop, probably by gift or inheritance; sold Sotheby's, 19 May 1958, lot 11 (£280 to the dealer Agnew's acting for Gwen, Lady Melchett); sold from Lady Melchett's collection, Christie's, 9 Nov. 1971, lot 74 (£2100 to the dealer Baskett and Day acting for Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon); given by Mellon in 1975 to the Yale Center for British Art.

desc.objtitle:
Title-Page Design for *The Grave* The Skeleton Re-Animated A Characteristic Frontispiece,
Object 1

objnote.p: The design is based on one or both passages in the poem describing the resurrection of the dead, pages 28 and 32 of the 1808 edition. Both passages refer to the quickening "trump"; only the first refers to a "strong lung'd cherub." The sheet is larger than any of the other designs in the group of twenty and extends to the edges of the cardboard mount. The text is in Blake's hand. Although the design may have been executed along with other illustrations to Blair's poem in Oct.-Nov. 1805, Blake could not have added the text before he had learned, in late Nov. or early Dec. 1805, that Louis Schiavonetti had been hired to engrave the designs. The "1806" date would in that case have been anticipatory or not added until that year. It is also possible that this water color was a later addition to the group, executed in the same year as the inscribed date. The design and a revised version of the text were etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in Robert Cromek's 1808 edition of *The Grave* . This is the only published design not listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805, although it might have been originally intended as the "characteristic Frontispiece" listed in that document. A possible preliminary sketch has been untraced since 1911 (Butlin 609). A water color drawing of the descending angel with a trumpet, now in the Yale Center for British Art, is also related (Butlin 611). An alternative title page design in water color, now in the Huntington Library (Butlin 616), is also dated 1806. That work is inscribed "A Series of Designs Invented & Engraved by William Blake" and may have been intended as a title page for a portfolio of drawings rather than prints.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male trumpeter hovers upside down in the right half of the design. He may be a wingless angel descending to awaken the skeleton below. His body faces forward with his genitals clearly visible. His head is bent back and faces down; he likely looks at the skeleton below. His hair is short and may also be curly. The figure's legs are together and extend up and to the left. His arms are bent and are raised vertically with respect to his body. He holds and plays a trumpet with his hands together and the fingers spread. A skeleton lies supine across the lower border of the design, facing up. The figure's legs are together and bent to the left. The skeleton's left arm rests at its side with the hand on the ground, palm down. Its right arm is bent over its shoulder; the skeleton appears to hold part of a cloth shroud with its right hand. The figure's head is up and bent back with its mouth open and teeth clearly visible. A stone(?) structure, perhaps part of a tomb or coffin, extends to the left of the skeleton. Fire surrounds the skeleton and a large cloud of smoke rises above and to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male trumpeter hovers upside down in the right half of the design. He may be a wingless angel descending to awaken the skeleton below. His body faces forward with his genitals clearly visible. His head is bent back and faces down; he likely looks at the skeleton below. His hair is short and may also be curly. The figure's legs are together and extend up and to the left. His arms are bent slightly and raised vertically with respect to his body. He holds and plays a trumpet or musical horn with his hands together and the fingers spread.

A skeleton lies supine across the lower border of the design, facing up. The figure's legs are together and bent to the left. The skeleton's left arm rests at its side with the hand on the ground and the palm down. Its right arm is bent over its shoulder; the skeleton appears to hold part of a cloth shroud with its right hand. The figure's head is up and bent back with its mouth open and teeth clearly visible.
A stone(?) structure, perhaps part of a tomb or coffin, extends to the left of the skeleton.
Fire surrounds the skeleton, and a large cloud of smoke rises above and to the right. There may be either some very dense billows of smoke or some large stones right of the skeleton.

texthead.l: The Grave The text was inscribed by Blake in pen and ink.

desc.objtitle:
Christ Descending into the Grave Christ Descending into the Grave, with the Keys of Death and Hell The Descent of Christ into the Grave,
Object 2

objnote.p: The design is based on the reference to the "Eternal King" and his "keys of hell and death," page 1 of the 1808 edition. A preliminary sketch is in the British Museum (Butlin 621); another possible preliminary sketch has been untraced since 1949 (Butlin 622). The design was etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in the 1808 edition.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christ stands in the center of the design, facing forward. He descends a set of stairs or steps with his left leg and foot prominent and his right leg bent back. Both feet are visible and his right foot is raised on tiptoe. Christ is gowned and has long, curly hair and a beard. A halo of light surrounds his head and shoulders, and beams of light radiate outward around his body. His arms are raised at 45 degrees and he holds a large key in each hand. Christ casts a shadow on the stairs to the left. A wall with an open doorway is visible at the top of the stairs. A (hellish?) fire burns along the lower border of the design; it appears to divide to the left and right at Christ's approach. The setting is mid-way between heaven, perhaps represented by the portal behind Christ, and the grave into which he descends.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ stands in the center of the design, facing forward. He descends a set of stairs with his left leg and foot prominent and his right leg bent back. Both feet are visible and his right foot is raised on tiptoe. Christ is gowned and has long, curly hair and a beard. A halo of light surrounds his head and shoulders, and beams of light radiate outward around his body. His arms are raised at 45 degrees and he holds a large key in each hand; these are probably the "keys of hell and death" referenced in the poem (page 1 of the 1808 edition). Each key bears the design of a cross. Christ casts a shadow on the stairs to the left.

Christ descends a set or stairs or steps, probably made of stone. A wall with an open doorway is visible at the top of the stairs. The setting is mid-way between heaven, perhaps represented by the portal behind Christ, and the grave into which he descends.

objtitle.title: The Gambols of Ghosts
The Gambols of Ghosts According with Their Affections Previous to the Final Judgement
The Gambols of the Ghosts According to Their Affections Previous to the Final Judgment

objnote.p: The design is based on the description of "light-heel'd ghosts" on page 2 of the 1808 edition. The backing mount is inscribed, not by Blake, with a few mostly erased words below the design. The last two words in this inscription may be "variously D . . . l . . . " or "virtuously D . . . l . . . " The back of the mount is inscribed, upper left, "Not"—probably meaning not engraved. A preliminary sketch is in the Yale Center for British Art (Butlin 636). The design was not published in the 1808 edition, nor is it listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a graveyard that stretches across the lower portion of the design. Two gravestones appear in the lower left corner and at least two tombs stand in the lower right corner. A Gothic church stands at the left border of the design. The roof is decorated with several sharply pointed spires and a cross is visible above a large, arched doorway. A single visible stair or step appears below the door. At least eleven figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. The leftmost figure stands in the doorway of the church and is seen from behind. Only the figure's left leg is clearly pictured. A gowned figure with a hood or veil stands second from the left. The figure's left arm is bent and he or she holds a lit candle. A pair of gowned figures (possibly children) stand third and fourth from the left. The child to the left faces forward and holds a lit candle with both hands. The child to the right is seen from behind and faces away. He or she likely holds the lit candle visible above. A pair of gowned males with long hair stand fifth and sixth from the left. The figure to the left is apparently in mid-stride with one leg bent forward. His left arm is bent and he holds an open book. His eyes are down and his mouth is open; he may be reading or speaking. The figure seventh from the left holds a plate or tray carrying loaves of bread or other food. The figure eighth from the left holds a candle with both hands and may represent a child. His or her mouth is open in an expression of fear or surprise; the figure may look at the ghosts below. Only the upper body of the figure ninth from the left is visible. The figure has long hair and faces left. The figure tenth from the left holds a tray carrying three glass goblets filled with dark liquid, possibly wine. The head of the figure furthest right is visible above a pair of legs resting on a tomb. The figure faces forward with his or her mouth open in an expression suggesting fear or surprise. The figure may look at the ghosts to the left and right. A leafy tree with distinct branches stands on a grassy hill in the center of the design. The full moon appears in the night sky to the left of the tree. Six figures run or dance to the left and right the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. The figure furthest left is seen from behind and bends or arches to the right with his or her left leg extended backward. The figure's right hand covers his or her face. The figure second from the left is seen from behind and strides to the right. The figure's right arm is bent upward, and the figure's right hand covers his or her face. Third from the left, a male with short, curly hair is seen from behind. He strides to the left with his left leg bent and right leg extended back to the right. The figure's arms are raised nearly horizontally with the palms held vertically and out away from his body. A gowned female appears fourth from the left. She runs to the right with her left foot raised on tiptoe and her right leg bent and raised off the ground. Both arms are bent upward; her right palm is turned out towards the viewer and her left palm is turned up. A gowned female with long hair appears fifth from the left. The figure runs to the left with her left leg bent forward and her left foot raised on tiptoe. Both arms are bent upward; her hands may clutch at her head. A nude male stands furthest right with his left leg bent and crossed behind his right; his left foot is raised off the ground. The figure is hunched over with his head down. Both arms are crossed and wrapped around his head. Twenty-six figures appear near the borders or corners of the design. The heads of two buried figures appear in the lower left corner of the design. The head to the left is turned up and faces right; the head to the right is bald and faces left. The upper bodies of two nude figures appear in the lower left portion of the design; the figures are partially buried in the earth. The figure to the left has long hair and may be female. She faces right with her head bent back and her mouth open. Her left arm rests on the ground and extends down and to the right; her left hand is curled into a fist. The figure to the right is male and has short hair. He faces forward with his head turned to the left; his mouth is open and he may look toward the figure to the left. The figure's right arm is bent upward with the hand curled into a fist; his left hand may rest on the ground to the right and is also curled into a fist. A nude, bald male lies on the ground at the lower border of the design with his torso horizontal. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his left leg is extended up and to the right; another ghost holds and likely pulls him by the ankle. His left arm is bent and rests on the ground; both hands grasp the tombstone to the left. A nude, bald male hovers or flies in the lower right portion of the design. Both arms are extended down and to the left; he grasps and may pull the ankle of the ghost below with both hands. A candle and an open book rest on the ground to the right of a tombstone along the lower border of the design. The candle is lit and appears to be placed in a candle holder. A bishop's croier (a staff with a coiled terminal) appears to the right. A nude male with short, curly hair crouches on a tomb in the lower right corner of the design. Both arms are down and he holds and pulls the hair of the buried figure below. The figure below is visible from the eyes up and may cast a shadow to the right. The upper body of a nude, bald figure appears in the lower right portion of the design. The figure faces right with its shoulders vertical and the top of its head facing the viewer. The figure's right arm is bent and wraps around, holds, or embraces the figure to the right. The bound figure faces right with her(?) head turned back to the left; the figure's mouth is open and she looks at the bald figure with an expression suggesting fear. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees and extend to the right with the palms held nearly vertically and out away from her body. A nude male(?) with short hair hovers or flies near the right border of the design; he is seen from behind with his head bent back. The figure's legs are bent and his right leg is drawn up to his chest. Both arms are raised vertically and he may be reaching toward, touching, or holding onto the figure above. A nude figure, probably female, with long hair flies or hovers near the right border of the design. The figure appears in a contracted position with both legs bent and her torso twisted down and to the right. The figure's head is bent back and faces up; her hair is pulled down by the figure below or possibly by the figure above. A nude male(?) with short hair flies or hovers above the contracted figure. The figure's left arm is bent over his shoulder and behind his back; he holds the left wrist of the figure below and may pull it upward. The figure's right arm is down, probably holding the contracted figure below. A gowned and old male with long hair and a beard flies or hovers in the upper right portion of the design; he faces left with his torso bent down and to the left. His mouth is open and he may be speaking or howling. The figure's left arm is raised horizontally (relative to his body) with the palm turned down. He may be wetting his left hand in order to sprinkle baptismal water on the child he holds. His right arm is bent and he holds or embraces the child to the left. The child faces forward and bends backward and to the left. The figure's mouth is open and he or she may be speaking or howling. The figure's right arm is bent slightly and may reach toward or touch the bearded male. A gowned female with long hair flies or hovers in the upper right corner of the design. The figure faces forward and slightly left with her head turned down; her eyes are closed and she may be smiling. Both arms are bent and she holds a plate or bowl with both hands. The upper body of a female flies or hovers in the upper right corner of the design. Her right arm is bent and she holds a pitcher with her right hand. Her left arm is not visible, but her left hand may cradle the pitcher from below with the palm turned up. The pitcher has a single curved handle and pours liquid into the bowl or plate below. A dark-skinned, bat-winged figure flies or hovers in the upper right portion of the design. The figure's left leg is bent and the right leg extends to the right. A gowned, bald male with a beard appears in the upper right portion of the design; he may be hovering or flying, or perhaps sits on the bat-winged figure. The figure's torso is twisted to the right with his right shoulder prominent. His right arm extends to the right and he holds an open book with his right hand. The bald head and left shoulder of a figure appear in the upper right portion of the design, just left of the male holding a book. Two nude ghosts (possibly children) fly or hover in the upper right portion of the design, above the bat-winged figure. The figures' bodies are horizontal and they hold a single lit candle; beams of light radiate outward from the flame. A gowned and old male with long hair and a beard flies or hovers near the upper border of the design, directly above the tree. The figure's body is horizontal and faces down with his head to the left. His right arm is bent back over his shoulder and he holds a knife or dagger in his right hand. A nude male with short, curly hair flies or hovers in the upper left portion of the design. The figure is twisted so that his lower body faces right and his upper body faces left. The figure's left arm is bent and he holds a small circular object, probably a ring, in his left hand. He may be offering marriage to the female to the left; if so, the old man with the dagger may be the female's angry father. The young man's right arm is raised horizontally and extends to the left; he holds the left wrist of the female to the left. The female is seen from behind and her hair is drawn back into a bun; she is partly nude and wears a skirt or other drapery. Her right arm is bent with the palm held vertically and out toward the man, as if to keep him away. Her left arm is bent upward with the palm turned away from the viewer and the fingers spread. A gowned female flies or hovers in the upper left portion of the design; the figure's long hair trails upward, suggesting that she may be falling or descending. Her body is positioned horizontally with both legs bent and drawn up and her arms raised horizontally relative to her body. She reaches for and apparently touches both the female above and the female below. A gowned female flies or hovers at the entrance of the church in the upper left portion of the design. The figure is upside down and bends backward and to the left; she may descend into the church. Her arms are only partially visible, but appear to be raised vertically with respect to her torso.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a graveyard that stretches across the lower portion of the design. Two gravestones appear in the lower left corner and at least two tombs stand in the lower right corner.

A Gothic church stands at the left border of the design. The roof is decorated with several sharply pointed spires and a cross is visible above a large, arched doorway. A single visible stair or step appears below the door.

At least eleven figures stand or walk in a procession to the right of the church. The leftmost figure stands in the doorway of the church and is seen from behind; only the figure's left leg is clearly pictured. The figure is gowned and his or her left leg is bent back with the left foot raised on tiptoe.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. A gowned figure with a hood or veil stands second from the left. The figure is seen from behind and faces left with his or her head down. Both legs are bent; the right foot rests on a step and the left foot is raised on tiptoe. The figure's left arm is bent and he or she holds a lit candle. Beams of light radiate outward from the flame.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. A pair of gowned figures (possibly children) stand third and fourth from the left. Both figures have long hair. The child to the left faces forward with his or her eyes raised. The figure's arms are bent and both hands hold a lit candle. Beams of light radiate outward from the candle's flame. The child to the right is seen from behind and faces away; he or she likely holds the lit candle that appears above.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. A pair of gowned males with long hair stand fifth and sixth from the left. Both figures are seen from behind and face to the left with their heads down. The figure to the left is apparently in mid-stride with one leg bent forward. His left arm is bent and he holds an open book. His eyes are down and his mouth is open; he may be reading and/or speaking. The figure to the right is partially obscured. The front-most figure may be old.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. Only the upper body of the seventh figure from the left is visible. He or she is seen from behind and faces left. The figure wears a gown and has long hair. The figure's left arm is bent and the left palm is turned up; he or she holds a plate or tray carrying loaves of bread or other food.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. The figure eighth from the left is positioned directly below the figure carrying a plate of bread. The figure's relative size suggests that he or she is a child. Only the child's head and arms are visible. His or her mouth is open in an expression of fear or surprise; the figure may look at the ghosts below. The child's arms are raised at 135 degrees and extend to the left; both hands grasp a lit candle. Beams of light radiate outward from the candle's flame.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. The upper body of a gowned figure appears ninth from the left. The figure has long hair and faces left. The figure may be holding a candle, the flame of which is visible above the head of the figure to the left.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. The upper body of a figure appears tenth from the left. The figure has long hair and may wear a gown. His or her left arm is bent with the palm turned up; the figure holds a tray carrying three glass goblets filled with dark liquid, possibly wine. The figure faces left.

At least eleven figures appear in a procession to the right of the church. The head of the figure furthest right is visible above a pair of legs resting on a tomb. The figure faces forward with his or her mouth open in an expression suggesting fear or surprise. The figure may look at the ghosts to the left and right.
Six lit candles appear among the procession of eleven figures. The bearers of these candles are not visible or immediately apparent. Beams of light radiate outward from the candles' flames.
A leafy tree with distinct branches stands on a grassy hill in the center of the design. Grass also covers the ground near the gravestones and tombs in the lower portion of the image.
The full moon appears in the night sky to the left of the tree.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. The figure furthest left is seen from behind, has short hair, and wears a gown. The figure bends or arches to the right with his or her left leg extended backward; the figure's left foot is raised on tiptoe. The figure's right hand covers his or her face.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. The figure second from the left is seen from behind, has short hair, and wears a gown. The figure strides to the right with its left leg bent forward and its right leg extended backward; the figure's right foot is raised on tiptoe. Both arms are bent upward, and the figure's right hand covers his or her face.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. Third from the left, a male with short, curly hair is seen from behind. The figure is apparently nude, but the traces of a gown or other drapery are visible above and below his right leg. He strides to the left with his left leg bent and right leg extended back to the right; his right foot is raised on tiptoe. The figure's arms are raised nearly horizontally with the palms held vertically. He faces away from the viewer and slightly left with his head turned to the right; his mouth may be open.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. A gowned female appears fourth from the left. She runs to the right with her left foot raised on tiptoe and her right leg bent and raised off the ground. Both arms are bent upward; her right palm is turned out towards the viewer and her left palm is turned up. The figure faces forward with her head turned up and to the left. Her eyes are raised.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. A gowned female with long hair appears fifth from the left. She faces left with her head turned up and to the right. Her eyes are raised. The figure runs to the left with her left leg bent forward and her left foot raised on tiptoe. Her right leg extends back to the right with the right foot raised off the ground. Both arms are bent upward. Her hands may clutch at her head; alternatively, her hands are positioned beside her head with the palms held vertically.

Six figures run or dance to the left and right the tree in the center of the design; they may represent ghosts. A nude male stands furthest right with his left leg bent and crossed behind his right; his left foot is raised off the ground. The figure is hunched over with his head down. He has short, curly hair. Both arms are crossed and wrap around his head.
A small fire is visible on a mound or hill to the right of the central tree, just right of the right foot of the figure with his arms wrapped around his head.
The heads of two figures appear in the lower left corner of the design. The figures may be buried. The head to the left is turned up and faces right. The head to the right is bald and faces left.

The upper bodies of two nude figures appear in the lower left portion of the design; the figures are partially buried in the earth. The figure to the left has long hair and may be female. She faces right with her head bent back and her mouth open; she may be speaking or howling. Her left arm rests on the ground and extends down and to the right; her left hand is curled into a fist.

The upper bodies of two nude figures appear in the lower left portion of the design: the figures are partially buried in the earth and may represent ghosts. The figure to the right is male and has short hair. He faces forward with his head turned to the left; his mouth is open and he may look toward the figure to the left. He may be speaking or howling. The figure's right arm is bent upward with the hand curled into a fist. His left hand may rest on the ground to the right and is also curled into a fist.

A nude male appears to the right of a tombstone along the lower border of the design. The figure is bald. He lies on the ground with his torso horizontal. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his left leg is extended up and to the right; another figure holds and likely pulls him by his left ankle. The figure faces forward with his head turned to the right; his eyes are raised and he likely looks at the figure grasping his ankle. His mouth is open and his expression may suggest anger or surprise. He may be speaking or howling. The figure's left arm is bent and rests on the ground; both hands grasp the tombstone to the left.

A nude male, possibly a ghost, hovers or flies in the lower right portion of the design. The figure is bald with traces of hair around his temples. He is seen from behind and is upside down. Both legs are bent with the sole of his left foot turned out towards the viewer. Both arms are extended down and to the left; he grasps and may pull the ankle of the ghost below with both hands.

A candle and an open book lie on the ground to the right of a tombstone along the lower border of the design. The candle is lit and appears to be placed in a candle holder. A bishop's crosier (a staff with a coiled finial) appears to the right.
The disembodied lower legs and feet of a figure rest or lie on a tomb in the lower right portion of the design.

A nude male, possibly a ghost, crouches on the lower edge of a tomb in the lower right corner of the design. Both legs are bent and his right foot may be raised on tiptoe. He faces forward with his head turned up and to the left. The figure has short, curly hair and his mouth is open. The figure's arms are both down; he holds and pulls the hair of the figure below.

The head of a buried figure, visible from the eyes up, appears in the lower right corner of the design. The head faces forward and may cast a shadow to the right. The figure's long hair is pulled upwards by the figure above.

The upper body of a nude, bald figure, probably male, appears in the lower right portion of the design. He may represent a ghost. The figure faces right with its shoulders vertical and the top of its head facing the viewer. The figure's right arm is bent and wraps around, holds, or embraces the figure to the right. They may be fighting.

The upper body of a nude(?) figure, probably female, with long hair appears in the lower right portion of the design. The figure is held by the bald figure to the left. The figure faces right with its head turned back to the left; the figure's mouth is open and he or she looks at the bald figure with an expression suggesting fear. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees and extend to the right with the palms held nearly vertically. The two figures may be fighting.

A nude male ghost hovers or flies near the right border of the design. He is seen from behind with his head bent back. His hair is short and possibly curly. The figure's legs are bent and his right leg is drawn up to his chest; both feet are visible and the sole of his left foot is turned out towards the viewer. Both arms are raised vertically. He may be reaching toward or touching or holding the figure above. He may be pulling the long hair of the female figure above.

A nude ghost with long hair, probably female, flies or hovers near the right border of the design. The figure appears in a contracted position with both legs bent and her torso twisted down and to the right; the figure is partially seen from behind. The figure's left arm is raised vertically and the right arm is bent and holds or touches the right arm of the figure above. The figure's head is bent back and faces up; her hair is pulled down by the figure below.

A nude male ghost with short hair flies or hovers near the right border of the design. The figure is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer. His left leg is bent slightly and the right leg is not pictured. The figure's left arm is bent over his shoulder and behind his back; he holds the left wrist of the figure below and may pull it upward. The figure's right arm is down and his right hand may also grasp the figure below.

A gowned and old male ghost flies or hovers in the upper right portion of the design. He faces left with his torso bent down and to the left. The figure has long hair and a beard. His mouth is open and he may be speaking or howling. The figure's left arm is raised horizontally (relative to his body) with the palm turned down. He may be dipping his hand in the water in the basin above him, perhaps to sprinkle baptismal water on the child. His right arm is bent and he holds or embraces the child to the left.

A nude(?) ghost is held by a gowned male in the upper right portion of the design. The figure may be hovering or flying. The figure's relative size suggests that he or she is a child. The child has short, possibly curly hair and its mouth is open; the figure may be speaking or howling. The child faces forward and bends backward and to the left. Both legs are bent to the left. The figure's right arm is bent slightly and may reach toward or touch or hold the bearded male to the right.

A female ghost flies or hovers in the upper right corner of the design. She is gowned and has long hair. The figure faces forward and slightly left. Her head is turned down; her eyes are closed and she may be smiling. Her left leg is bent to the right. Both arms are bent and she holds a plate or bowl with both hands.

The upper body of a female ghost appears in the upper right corner of the design; she may be flying or hovering. The figure faces forward with her head turned to the right; she may look down toward the figure below. Her right arm is bent and she holds a pitcher with her right hand. Her left arm is not visible, but her left hand may cradle the pitcher from below with the palm turned up. The pitcher has a single curved handle and pours liquid, perhaps baptismal water, into the bowl or plate below.

A dark-skinned, bat-winged figure flies or hovers in the upper right portion of the design; the figure is likely a ghost. The figure is bald, nude, and seen from behind. The figure's left leg is bent and the right leg extends to the right.

A gowned male ghost appears in the upper right portion of the design; he may be hovering or flying, or perhaps sits on the bat-winged figure. The figure is bald and has a long beard. His left leg is bent and drawn up; his right leg extends down and to the right. The figure's torso is twisted to the right with his right shoulder prominent. His right arm extends to the right and he holds an open book with his right hand.
The head and left shoulder of a ghost appear in the upper right portion of the design. The figure is bald and faces left in profile. It may be hovering or flying.

Two nude ghosts, probably children or putti, fly or hover in the upper right portion of the design, above the bat-winged figure. Both figures' bodies are horizontal with their heads to the left. The figure to the right may have short, curly hair. His or her left leg is bent and the right leg extends to the right. Both figures hold the same lit candle; beams of light radiate outward from the flame.

An old male ghost with long hair and a beard flies or hovers near the upper border of the design, directly above the tree. The figure is gowned. His body is horizontal and faces down with his head to the left. The figure's right leg extends to the right; his left leg is bent with the sole of his left foot turned out toward the viewer. Both arms are bent. He points to the left with his left hand. His right arm is bent back over his shoulder and he holds a knife or dagger in his right hand. He may be the angry father of the female to the left. His mouth is open and he may be speaking.

A nude male ghost flies or hovers in the upper left portion of the design. The figure is twisted so that his lower body faces right and his upper body faces left. His head is turned to the right and he likely looks and the gowned male to the right. The figure's hair is short and curly. Both legs are bent to the left. His right arm is raised horizontally and extends to the left; he holds the left wrist of the female to the left. The figure's left arm is bent and he holds a small circular object, probably a ring, in his left hand. He may be offering marriage to the female to the left.

A female ghost flies or hovers in the upper left portion of the design. She is seen from behind and her hair is drawn back into a bun. The figure is partly nude and wears a skirt or other drapery. Both legs are bent and the sole of her left foot is turned out towards the viewer. Her right arm is bent with the palm held vertically. Her left arm is bent upward with the palm turned out away from the viewer and the fingers spread; the figure to the right holds her left wrist. The female faces away with her head turned to the right and her mouth open; she likely looks at the male to the right. She may be the daughter of the angry man to the right holding a dagger.

A gowned female ghost flies or hovers in the upper left portion of the design. The figure's long hair trails upward, suggesting that she may be falling or descending. The figure's body is positioned horizontally with both legs bent and drawn up. Her arms are raised horizontally relative to her body. She reaches for and apparently touches or holds both the female above and the female below. The figure's head is turned up and she likely looks at the female above.

A gowned female ghost flies or hovers at the entrance of the church in the upper left portion of the design. The figure is upside down and bends backward and to the left; she may descend into the church. The figure's head is bent back and she has long hair. Her arms are only partially visible, but appear to be raised vertically with respect to her torso.

desc.objtitle:
The Widow Embracing her Husband's Grave A Widow Embracing the Turf which Covers her Husband's Grave,
Object 4 (Butlin 633)

objnote.p: The design illustrates the description of "the new-made widow" on page 4 of the 1808 edition. The backing mount inscriptions below the design were probably written by Blake in brown ink, then partly over-written by another hand in black ink; see Related Works in the Archive. This water color was separated from its nineteen companions at an unknown time, probably in the early- or mid-nineteenth century (see the note on provenance on the Work Information page). The design is listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805, but it was not published in the 1808 edition. A preliminary sketch is in the British Museum (Butlin 634).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a graveyard that stretches across the lower portion of the design. As many as fourteen tombstones appear throughout the graveyard; three of the stones are apparently inscribed, but the writing is indecipherable. At least three tombs also appear in the graveyard. A mound suggesting a fresh grave appears in the lower left corner; it is bound with three thorny vines. A gowned female lies on the mound. Her body is horizontal with her head to the left. Her mourning gown is dark and she wears a veil over her long hair. The figure's left arm is bent and her right arm is raised vertically with respect to her body. Both arms rest on the ground; her right palm is turned down and the fingers on her left hand are spread slightly. The woman's eyes are raised and she wears an expression of grief or despair. Two figures stand or walk along a path in the right half of the design. The figure to the left is a gowned female. She has curly hair and wears a hat. Her arms are bent with the palms held vertically in front of her chest; the fingers on both hands are spread. The male figure to the right wears a shirt, breeches, possibly stockings, shoes, and a hat. His left leg is bent with his left foot raised on tiptoe. His left arm is raised at approximately 45 degrees; the palm is turned down and he may point to the right. His right arm is obscured by the female, but the position of his right hand suggests that it is also raised at 45 degrees. His right hand is held down with the palm vertical and the fingers spread. Both figures' heads are turned down and to the right; they looks towards the widow below with expressions of surprise or pity. A low stone wall is visible to the left and right of the couple. A Gothic church stands in the upper central portion of the design. Two windows and a doorway with pointed arches are visible on the building's facade. The roof is decorated with a series of spires. The ground below the figures and gravestones is covered with grass. Leafy trees appear in the distance to the left and right of the church; the leftmost tree has a distinct trunk and visible branches. The sky is filled with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a graveyard that stretches across the lower portion of the design. As many as fourteen tombstones appear throughout the graveyard; three of the stones are apparently inscribed, but the writing is indecipherable. At least three tombs also appear in the graveyard. A mound suggesting a fresh grave appears in the lower left corner. It is bound with three thorny vines.

A gowned female lies on the mound of a fresh grave in the lower portion of the design. Her body is horizontal with her head to the left. She lies on her side and faces the viewer with her torso twisted to face downward. Her mourning gown is dark and she wears a veil over her long hair. The figure's left arm is bent and her right arm is raised vertically with respect to her body. Both arms rest on the ground; her right palm is turned down and the fingers on her left hand are spread slightly. The woman's eyes are raised and she wears an expression of grief or despair.

Two figures stand or walk along a path in the right half of the design. The figure to the left is a gowned female. She has curly hair and wears a hat. Her arms are bent with the palms held vertically in front of her chest; the fingers on both hands are spread. She faces forward with her head turned down and to the right; she looks towards the widow below with an expression of surprise or pity.

Two figures stand or walk on a path in the right half of the design. The male figure to the right wears a shirt, breeches, possibly stockings, shoes, and a hat. He has short, curly hair. His left leg is bent with his left foot raised on tiptoe. His left arm is raised at approximately 45 degrees; the palm is turned down and he may point to the right. His right arm is obscured by the female, but the position of his right hand suggests that it is also raised at 45 degrees. His right hand is held upside down with the palm vertical and the fingers spread slightly. The figure faces right with his head turned down and to the left; he looks towards the widow below with an expression of surprise or pity.
A Gothic church stands in the upper central portion of the design. Two windows and a doorway with pointed arches are visible on the building's facade. The roof is decorated with a series of spires.
The couple stands or walks on a path that extends horizontally from the door of the church toward the right border of the design.
A low stone wall is visible to the left and right of the couple standing in the right half of the design.

The ground below the figures and gravestones is covered with grass. Leafy trees appear in the distance to the left and right of the church; the leftmost tree has a distinct trunk and visible branches.
Washes in the upper portion of the design represent a cloudy sky.

desc.objtitle:
The Widow Embracing her Husband's Grave: full view including mount inscriptions A Widow Embracing the Turf which Covers her Husband's Grave: full view including mount inscriptions,
full view including mount inscriptions (Butlin 633)

objnote.p: The mount inscriptions were probably written by Blake in brown ink, then partly over-written by another hand in black ink. See the Textual Transcription. This water color was separated from its 19 companions at an unknown time, probably in the early- or mid-nineteenth century (see the note on provenance on the Work Information page). The design is listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805, but it was not published in the 1808 edition. A preliminary sketch is in the British Museum (Butlin 634).

lg.l: Prone on the lowly grave ___ she drops__
Clings yet more closely to the senseless turf.
Nor heeds the passenger who looks that way.

The Widow Embracing her Husband's Grave: bottom mount inscriptions A Widow Embracing the Turf which Covers her Husband's Grave: bottom mount inscriptions,
bottom mount inscriptions (Butlin 633)

This water color was separated from its 19 companions at an unknown time, probably in the early- or mid-nineteenth century (see the note on provenance on the Work Information page). The design is listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805, but it was not published in the 1808 edition. A preliminary sketch is in the British Museum (Butlin 634).

lg.l: Prone on the lowly grave ___ she drops__
Clings yet more closely to the senseless turf.
Nor heeds the passenger who looks that way.

desc.objtitle:
Friendship There's no Bye-Road to Bliss,
Object 5

objnote.p: The design illustrates the description of "Friendship" on pages 4-5 of the 1808 edition. The mount is inscribed, not by Blake, "Friendship," below the design. The back of the mount is inscribed, upper right, "Not"—probably meaning not engraved. The design is listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805, but it was not published in the 1808 edition.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two male figures stand on a path in the center of the design; both are seen from behind. The figure to the left has long, curly hair and a short beard. He wears a long gown and a hat. His mouth may be open slightly; he may be speaking. His left arm is raised and he points to the right with his extended forefinger. His right arm is down at his side and he holds hands with the figure to the right (or at least touches his hand). The figure to the right has long hair. He wears a knee-length gown and a hat. His right arm is down at his side and he holds a walking stick in his right hand. Both figures stand with their right legs bent and their right feet raised on tiptoe; they may walk away from the viewer. The path leads to a city in the distance; the city is raised on a hill or mountain with cliffs to the left. The buildings are decorated with multiple spires and pointed arches possibly representing doors or windows; the architecture suggests a Gothic style. The building furthest left may have a domed roof. Beams of light radiate outward from the city. A large stone appears in the foreground to the right of the two figures. Grass grows to the left and right of the two figures. A vine-like plant with six small buds and some spiky vegetation appear to the left. Another plant with two large leaves at its base and two arched stems, as well as more spiky vegetation (perhaps grass), grow to the right. Wash above the city indicates a cloudy sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Two male figures stand on a path in the center of the design; both are seen from behind. The figure to the left has long, curly hair and a short beard. He wears a long gown and a hat. His mouth is open slightly; he may be speaking. His right arm is down at his side and he holds hands with the figure to the right (or at least their hands touch). His left arm is raised and he points to the right with his extended forefinger. The figure's right leg is bent with his right foot raised on tiptoe; he likely walks away from the viewer.

Two male figures stand on a path in the center of the design; both are seen from behind. The figure to the right has long hair. He wears a knee-length gown and a hat. His left arm is bent slightly and he holds hands with the figure to the left (or at least their hands touch). His right arm is down at his side and he holds a walking stick in his right hand. The figure's right left is bent with his right foot raised on tiptoe; he may walk away from the viewer.

The two figures stand on a path in the center of the design. The path leads to a city in the distance; the city is raised on a hill or mountain with cliffs to the left. A large stone appears in the foreground to the right of the two figures.

Spiky plants, perhaps grass, grow to the left and right of the two figures. A vine-like plant with six small buds appears to the left. Another plant with two large leaves at its base and two arched stems grows to the right.

A distant city appears to the left and right of the two figures. The buildings are decorated with multiple spires and pointed arches possible representing doors or windows; the architecture suggests a Gothic style. The building furthest left may have a domed roof. Beams of light radiate outward from the city.
Wash above the city indicates a cloudy sky.

desc.objtitle:
The Counseller, King, Warrior, Mother & Child, in the Tomb The Counselor, King, Warrior, Mother & Child, in the Tomb The Counsellor, King, Warrior, Mother, and Child The Councilor, King, Warrior, Mother & Child, in the Tomb The Councillor, King, Warrior, Mother & Child, in the Tomb,
Object 6

objnote.p: The design does not illustrate a specific passage in the poem but addresses the general theme of death as a leveler. The design was etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in the 1808 edition, where it faces page 11 and can be associated with the text beginning on that page. Blake developed the design on the basis of his monochrome wash drawing of the same title datable to c. 1780-85 and now in a private British collection (Butlin 136).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five corpses lay supine in an ornate tomb. The ceiling of the tomb arches above the central figures. The tomb is probably made of stone. The figures lay horizontally on a woven mat; it may be made of straw. Their heads rest on pillows to the left. The lowest figure is a gowned male with long hair and a beard; he likely represents a counselor. His right arm rests at his side and he holds a partially unrolled scroll in his right hand. A seal dangles from the lower end of the scroll. The second figure from the bottom is a gowned male with long, curly hair and a short beard. He wears a crown and likely represents a king; his right arm rests at his side and he holds a scepter with his right hand. The third figure from the bottom is a male figure wearing armor and a plumed helmet; he likely represents a warrior, knight or soldier. The warrior holds a sheathed sword with both hands. His feet rest on the back and head of a sculpted animal, probably a lion. The fourth figure from the bottom is a gowned female with long hair. Her left arm rests at her side with her hand resting on the child above; she is likely the child's mother. The child is gowned and has curly hair. The left and upper walls of the tomb are lined with Gothic arches or small niches, perhaps eighteen in all; at least four of these contain statues. Two winged angel statues stand to the left and right of the oil lamp, facing forward. Both angels are gowned and may have long hair. Their arms are apparently down at their sides. The statue of a female(?) stands along the left border of the design, left of the king's head. She has long hair and wears a crown and a cloak or gown. Above and to the right stands a statue of a gowned male. Both statues face right. Three Gothic arches appear in the center of the upper wall, directly above the child; a shelf is recessed behind the arches. An oil lamp burns above the figures on the shelf; the lamp's handle forms a loop. Fourteen figures appear along the upper and lower borders of the design; they may represent statues or carvings on the tomb. Six winged angels appear above the arch of the ceiling. The figures appear to lay prone against the arch; each has one arm bent upward in front of its chest. Eight gowned figures appear along the lower border of the image. The figures lay on their sides in a reclining position. Each figure appears to rest its head on its hand. Vegetative motifs, possibly leaves, appear in the upper corners of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Five corpses lay supine in an ornate tomb; the figures' bodies extend horizontally across the design with their heads to the left. The lowest figure is a gowned male with long hair and a beard. He very probably represents the counselor ("Counseller") named in the inscription on Schiavonetti's engraving of the design. The figure's legs are together and both feet are visible. His right arm rests at his side and he holds a partially unrolled scroll in his right hand. A seal dangles from the lower end of the scroll. His eyes are closed.

Five corpses lay supine in an ornate tomb; the figures' bodies extend horizontally across the design with their heads to the left. The second figure from the bottom is a gowned male with long, curly hair and a short beard. He wears a crown. He is very probably the king named in the inscription on Schiavonetti's engraving of the design. His eyes are raised. The figure's legs are together and extend to the right; he may wear shoes. His right arm rests at his side and he holds a scepter, with a fleur-de-lis finial, in his right hand.

Five corpses lay supine in an ornate tomb; the figures' bodies extend horizontally across the design with their heads to the left. The third figure from the bottom is a male figure apparently wearing armor. He is very probably the soldier or "Warrior" named in the inscription on Schiavonetti's engraving of the design. The figure wears a helmet with a large plume. A belt or sash is visible around his waist. His legs are crossed at the knees with the left over the right; he may wear spurs. The warrior's right arm is bent upwards and he grasps the hilt of a sheathed sword with his right hand; his left arm is at his side and he holds the sheath with his left hand. He has a mustache but is not bearded. His eyes are raised. His feet rest on the back and head of a sculpted animal, probably a lion.

Five corpses lay supine in an ornate tomb; the figures' bodies extend horizontally across the design with their heads to the left. The fourth figure from the bottom is a gowned female with long hair. Her eyes are closed. The figure's legs are together and extend to the right. She may wear shoes. Her left arm rests at her side with her hand resting on the child above; she is probably the "Mother" (of the child) named in the inscription on Schiavonetti's engraving of the design.

Five corpses lay supine in an ornate tomb; the figures' bodies extend horizontally across the design with their heads to the left. The uppermost figure is a gowned child with curly hair. His or her eyes are closed. The child's legs are together and extend to the right; both feet are visible. The child's arms are not pictured. This is the "Child" named in the inscription on Schiavonetti's engraving of the design.

Five figures lay in an ornate tomb. The left and upper walls of the tomb are lined with Gothic arches or small niches, perhaps eighteen in all. At least four of these contain statues. Three Gothic arches appear in the center of the upper wall, directly above the figure of the child; a shelf is recessed behind the arches. The ceiling of the tomb arches above the figures. Several statues or decorative carvings appear above and below the five central figures. The tomb is probably made of stone.
The five figures lay on a woven mat; it may be made of straw. Their heads rest on pillows.
An oil lamp burns above the figures on a recessed shelf. The lamp's handle forms a loop.
Vegetative motifs, possibly leaves, appear in the upper corners of the design.

A total of eighteen decorative figures appear within the tomb. Two winged angel statues stand to the left and right of the oil lamp, facing forward. Both angels are gowned and may have long hair. Their arms are apparently down at their sides. The statue of a female(?) stands along the left border of the design, left of the king's head. She has long hair and wears a cloak or gown. Above and to the right stands a statue of a gowned male. Both statues face right. Fourteen figures appear along the upper and lower borders of the design; they may represent statues or carvings on the tomb. Six winged angels appear above the arch of the ceiling. The figures appear to lay prone against the arch; each has one arm bent upward in front of its chest. Eight gowned figures appear along the lower border of the image. The figures lay on their sides in a reclining position. Each figure appears to rest its head on its hand.

desc.objtitle:
Whilst Surfeited Upon Thy Damask Cheek Whilst Surfeited Upon Thy Damask Cheek, the High-fed Worm in Lazy Volumes Roll'd, Riots Unscar'd Whilst Surfeited Upon Thy Damask Cheek, the High-fed Worm in Lazy Volumes Rolled, Riots Unscarred,
Object 7

objnote.p: The design illustrates lines, quoted in part in its title, on page 11 of the 1808 edition. The design was not published in the 1808 edition, nor is it listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures stand in a graveyard with two tombstones visible. A gowned female stands to the left, an open grave below here. Her long hair appears to be drawn back with a few locks visible above her left shoulder. She wears a crown or wreath of flowers in her hair. The figure's right arm is bent upwards and she points to her cheek with her right hand. Her left arm is down at her side and she points towards a worm with her left hand. The worm rests on the ground between the two figures. A male with short, curly hair stands to the right with his legs spread apart. His mouth may be open. He wears a shirt, breeches, possibly stockings, and shoes; there may be two buttons on the left leg of his breeches. The figure's arms are bent and cross at the wrists with his hands covering his chest. He faces left in profile with his head turned down; he looks at the worm below. A Gothic church stands in the left portion of the design. The roof is decorated with several sharply pointed spires. A cross is visible above an arched entryway and a single step is pictured below the arch. Two arched windows with visible tracery appear to the left and right of the entryway. There may be a statue of a gowned figure in a niche in the wall just within the entry to the church. A path extends horizontally across the design from the entryway of the church to the right border of the image. The ground below the figures is covered with grass. A small flower or bud appears on the ground to the right of the male figure. A mass of leafy, indeterminate vegetation above a stone wall may suggest a distant forest of trees. A distant mountain rises above a river, stream, or road to the right of the male character. Clouds fill the upper portion of the sky. The disc of the sun appears on the horizon between the male and female figures. Beams of light are visible radiating from the sun; it may be sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female stands in the left half of the design. Her long hair appears to be drawn back with a few locks visible above her left shoulder. She wears a crown or wreath of flowers in her hair. She faces forward with her head turned to the right; she looks at the male figure to the right. The figure's right arm is bent upwards and she points to (and possibly touches) her cheek with her right hand. Her left arm is down at her side and she points towards a worm with her left hand.
A worm crawls on the ground between the male and female figures.

A male with short, curly hair stands in the right half of the design with his legs spread apart. His mouth may be open. He wears a shirt, breeches, possibly stockings, and shoes; there may be two buttons on the left leg of his breeches. The figure's arms are bent and cross at the wrists with his hands covering his chest. He faces left in profile with his head turned down; he looks at the worm below. Dark shadows extend below and to the right of the man's feet.

A Gothic church stands in the left portion of the design. The roof is decorated with several sharply-pointed spires. A cross is visible above an arched entryway and a single step is pictured below the arch. Two arched windows with visible tracery appear to the left and right of the entryway. There may be a statue of a gowned figure in a niche in the wall just within the doorway.

The two figures stand in a graveyard with two tombstones visible. An open grave appears below the female. An indistinct inscription appears on the tombstone to the left. A stone wall stands above the tombstones. A path extends horizontally across the design from the entryway of the church to the right border of the image.

The ground below the figures is covered with grass. A small flower or bud among spiky leaves appears on the ground to the right of the male figure. A mass of leafy, indeterminate vegetation above the stone wall may suggest a distant forest of trees.
A distant mountain rises above a river, stream, or road visible to the right of the male figure.

Clouds fill the upper portion of the sky. The disc of the sun appears on the horizon between the male and female figures. Beams of light are visible radiating from the sun; it may be sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle:
Death of the Strong Wicked Man The Strong and Wicked Man Dying,
Object 8

objnote.p: The design illustrates the death of the strong man described on page 12 of the 1808 edition. A preliminary sketch is in the Victoria and Albert Museum (Butlin 624 recto). The design was etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in the 1808 edition.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a room with an open window in the upper left portion of the wall. The body of a muscular male figure lies partly supine, partly on its side, in the lower half of the design. In the inscriptions in Schiavonetti's engraving of the design, he is identified as the "Strong Wicked Man." He lies on a woven mat, possibly made of straw, and a sheet or bundle of sheets. He is partly nude with a loincloth or sheet covering his genitals. The figure's head is bent back and rests on his left shoulder. The figure's legs are together and extend to the left. Both arms are bent and rest at his side; he clutches at a sheet with both hands. He is dying and may even be dead. A broken chalice or goblet appears to the left of the corpse's left hand; liquid spills out to the left. A nude, muscular male flies or hovers in the upper portion of the design. This figure probably represents the spirit of the male figure below. The spirit is surrounded by fire; the flames rise up and to the left and may pass through the open window. The spirit is seen from behind and rises up and to the left with his body nearly horizontal. His right leg is extended down and to the right with his left leg bent and drawn up; the sole of his left foot is turned out toward the viewer. The figure's head is turned to the left in profile; his mouth is open and he wears an expression of surprise or fear. The spirit's left arm is bent to the left with the palm held vertically; his right arm is not clearly pictured, but his right hand is also held vertically left of his head. A gowned female with long hair kneels or lunges above the corpse with her body horizontal. Her mouth is open and she looks down and to the right toward the corpse below; her expression and posture suggest grief or despair. Her right leg is bent and drawn up; her left leg extends to the left with her foot raised on tiptoe. Both arms are bent with her hands positioned beside her head; her palms are nearly vertical with respect to her head and her fingers are spread slightly. A gowned female with long hair stands at the right border of the design. She faces left in profile. Her left foot is visible below the hem of her gown. The figure's head is turned down; her left arm is bent and she covers her face with her left hand. Her posture suggests grief or despair.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a room with an open window in the upper left portion of the wall.
A mountain or series of mountains are visible through the open window.

The dying man lies on a woven mat, possibly made of straw, and a sheet or bundle of sheets. A broken chalice or goblet (possibly made of glass) appears to the left of the corpse's left hand; liquid spills out to the left. A chair or bench stands to the left of the figures, just below the open window.

The body of a muscular male figure lies partly supine, partly on its side, in the lower portion of the design. In the inscription in Schiavonetti's engraving of the design, he is identified as the "Strong Wicked Man." He is partly nude with a loincloth or sheet covering his genitals. The figure's head is bent back and rests on his left shoulder; he has short, curly hair and his mouth is open with teeth visible. The figure's legs are together and extend to the left. Both arms are bent and rest at his side; he clutches at a sheet with both hands. He is dying and may even be dead.

A nude, muscular male flies or hovers in the upper portion of the design. This figure probably represents the spirit of the dying male below. The spirit is seen from behind and rises up and to the left with his body nearly horizontal. His right leg is extended down and to the right with his left leg bent and drawn up; the sole of his left foot is turned out toward the viewer. The figure's head is turned to the left in profile; his mouth is open and he wears an expression of surprise or fear. His hair is short and curly. The spirit's left arm is bent to the left with the palm held vertically. His right arm is not clearly pictured, but his right hand is also held vertically left of his head. His fingers are spread slightly. His left ear and buttocks are prominent.
The spirit is surrounded by fire; the flames rise up and to the left and may pass through the open window.

A gowned female with long hair kneels or lunges above the corpse with her body horizontal. Her mouth is open, teeth visible, and she looks down and to the right toward the corpse below; her expression and posture suggest grief or despair. Her right leg is bent and drawn up. Her left leg extends to the left with her foot raised on tiptoe. Both arms are bent with her hands positioned beside her head; her palms are nearly vertical with respect to her head and her fingers are spread slightly.

A gowned female with long hair stands at the right border of the design. She faces left in profile. Her left foot is visible below the hem of her gown. The figure's head is turned down; her left arm is bent and she covers her face with her left hand. Her posture suggests grief or despair.

desc.objtitle:
The Soul Hovering over the Body The Soul Suspended over the Body, Unwilling to Part with Life The Soul Hovering over the Body Reluctantly Parting with Life,
Object 9

objnote.p: The design illustrates the description of the soul leaving the body, page 16 of the 1808 edition. A preliminary sketch is in the Tate Collection (Butlin 625). There are three possibly related drawings, all untraced since the 1860s (Butlin 626-28). The design was etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in the 1808 edition.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a room with a window in the upper left portion of the wall. An arch is visible on the wall to the right of the window. A series of mountains appear through the window. There may be water in the lower left portion of the landscape, representing a lake, river, or the sea. A sky with visible clouds is pictured above the mountains. The corpse of a gowned male lays supine on a bier in the lower half of the design. The bier is covered with a sheet and the corpse rests on a partially rolled mat or cushion. His body is horizontal with his head to the right. The figure has curly hair and his eyes are closed. A gowned female with long hair hovers above the corpse; she likely represents the male figure's soul or spirit. She leans or arches to the right above the corpse with her legs extended together down and to the left. Her head is turned down and she looks at the corpse below. Both arms are bent with her hands held beside her head and the palms turned out towards the viewer; the fingers on both hands are spread slightly. Her mouth may be slightly open.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in a room with a window in the upper left portion of the wall. An arch is visible on the wall to the right of the window. The dark area at the foot of the bier may be a shadow.

A series of mountains is visible through the window. There may be water in the lower left portion of the landscape, representing a lake, river, or the sea. A sky with visible clouds is pictured above the mountains.
Several buildings, including one with a tall spire, are visible below the leftmost mountain. They may represent a distant city.

The corpse of a gowned male lays supine on a bier in the lower half of the design. His body is horizontal with his head to the right. The figure has curly hair and his eyes are closed. Both feet are visible and rest on a partially rolled mat or cushion.
A corpse rests on a bier in the lower half of the design. The bier is covered with a sheet. The corpse lays on a partially rolled mat or cushion.

A gowned female with long hair hovers above the corpse; she likely represents the male figure's soul or spirit. She leans or arches to the right above the corpse with her legs extended together down and to the left. Her head is turned down and she looks at the corpse below. Both arms are bent with her hands held beside her head and the palms turned out towards the viewer; the fingers on both hands are spread slightly. Her mouth may be slightly open.

desc.objtitle:
Our Time is Fix'd Our Time is Fixed Our Time is Fix'd, and All Our Days are Number'd Our Time is Fixed, and All our Days are Numbered> A Characteristic Frontispiece Friendship ,
Object 10

objnote.p: The design may be based on a single line, "Our time is fix'd, and all our days are number'd," page 18 of the 1808 edition. The mount is inscribed, not by Blake, in pencil below the design. This inscription is largely erased and is illegible. The back of the mount is inscribed, upper right, "Not"—probably meaning not engraved. The design was not published in the 1808 edition. It is not listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805, but it might have been originally intended as the "characteristic Frontispiece" listed in that document.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Fourteen figures fly or hover around a crescent moon; each figure holds a continuous string or strand of thread. A nude female with long hair appears in the upper left corner of the group.
