Two columns of smoke or clouds extend upward toward the top left and right corners of the design, forming a V-shape behind the figures.Light wash respresenting sky appears between the two columns of clouds or smoke; coloring may suggest sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle:
Death's Door Deaths Door The Door of Death,
Object 16

objnote.p: The design illustrates the entry into the grave, when "we make the grave our bed," page 32 of the 1808 edition. A sheet of pencil sketches, now in the Carnegie Institute Museum of Art, may be preliminary to this design (Butlin 632 recto and verso). Blake etched the design in white line in 1805, but this was rejected by the publisher, Robert Cromek. The design was then etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in the 1808 edition.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A tomb is built into a large stone or hill in the lower portion of the design. The doorway is framed by two pillars supporting a lintel and a single step below. There may be a path or road below the tomb, along the lower border of the image. Leafy vegetation appears in the lower right corner of the design along the right edge of the path or road. The door to the tomb is open with a hinge visible along its right edge. Large straps, possibly made of iron, secure the structure of the wooden(?) door. A circular knocker or handle appears in the center of the door, and a keyhole is visible below and to the left. The interior of the tomb is dark. A woven mat, possibly made of straw, rests on a bier, bed, or raised platform in the lower left corner of the tomb. An old man with long hair and a beard stands in the lower portion of the design. The figure wears a belted gown and faces left in profile. His left leg is bent with his left heel raised slightly. His right leg is not pictured, but he likely steps up into the doorway. The figure is hunched over and leans on a crutch positioned under his left arm. The figure's left arm is bent at his side and he may hold or touch the crutch with his left hand. The old man's long hair streams out to the left, as though blown by a wind. A nude male with short curly hair sits or kneels above the tomb. The figure faces forward with his head turned up and to the right in profile. His mouth is open and his right eye is raised. Both legs are bent; his left knee is on the ground and his right leg is drawn up. The figure's left arm is at his side and is not visible below the elbow. His right arm is bent back; his hand rests on the ground with the palm down and he may be bracing or supporting himself. An aura surrounds the upper half of the figure; beams of light radiate outward. Alternatively, the figure may be positioned in front of the sun at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A tomb is built into a large stone or hill in the lower portion of the design. The doorway is framed by two pillars supporting a lintel and a single step below. There may be a path or road below the tomb, along the lower border of the image. The door to the tomb is open with a hinge visible along its right edge, just above the old man's back. A circular knocker or handle appears in the center of the door, and a keyhole is visible below and to the left. Large straps, perhaps made of iron, secure the structure of the wooden(?) door. The interior of the tomb is dark. A woven mat, possibly made of straw, rests on a stone bed, bier, or raised platform in the lower left corner of the tomb. The left end of the mat is coiled.

Leafy vegetation appears in the lower right corner of the design along the right edge of the path or road. A cluster of three flowers with distinct stems and petals grows just right of the tomb. There are slight indications of grass or other vegetation on the rocks above the tomb, to the left and right of the kneeling figure's foot.

An old male with long hair and a beard stands in the lower portion of the design. The figure wears a belted gown and faces left in profile. His left leg is bent with his left heel raised slightly. His right leg is not pictured, but he likely steps up into the doorway. The figure is hunched over and leans on a crutch positioned under his left arm. The figure's left arm is bent at his side and he may hold or touch the crutch with his left hand. His long hair streams out to the left, as though blown by a wind.

A nude male with short curly hair sits or kneels above the tomb. The figure faces forward with his head turned up and to the right in profile. His mouth is open and his right eye is raised. Both legs are bent; his left knee is on the ground and his right leg is drawn up. His right arm is bent back; his hand rests on the ground with the palm down and he may be bracing or supporting himself. Only the figure's left shoulder is visible, but his left arm may be drawn back. An aura surrounds the upper half of the figure; beams of light radiate outward. Alternatively, the figure may be positioned in front of the sun.
The sun may appear in the sky behind the nude male; beams of light radiate outward. Coloring in the sky may suggest sunrise or sunset. Darkness or shadow appears to the right of the tomb.

desc.objtitle:
The Meeting of a Family in Heaven A Family Meeting in Heaven,
Object 17

objnote.p: The design does not illustrate any specific passage in the poem, but it may be related to the comparison of the reunion of the soul and the body to "th' Impatience of a man / That's new come home," page 32 of the 1808 edition. A preliminary sketch is in the British Museum (Butlin 623). The design was etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in the 1808 edition.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two gowned angels fly or hover above a family of seven. Their wings may touch at the upper border of the design. The angels face towards the center and look down at the figures below. A male and a female child kneel or crouch furthest left. The female is seen from behind and faces away. The male figure's arms are bent and wrap around the waist of the female; her arms wrap around his neck and shoulders. The figures are embracing and may also be kissing. A male and female adult couple stand third and fourth from the left; they are probably the father and mother of the children to the left and right. The father faces right with his head turned down; the mother faces left with her head turned up. The couple are embracing and kissing. His right arm is bent and wraps around the back of the female; his left hand holds her buttocks. The female's arms are bent and wrap around the male's neck; her right hand rests on the male's right shoulder with the fingers spread slightly. A male child and female child stand fifth and sixth from the left; only the male's upper body is clearly visible. The male's arms are bent and wrap around the waist of the female child; the figures are embracing and may be kissing. A male child stands furthest right with his mouth open. He faces left with his right leg bent back and his right foot raised on tiptoe; he may be walking or running. His arms are raised at 135 degrees and extend to the left with the palms held vertically; he may be reaching towards his mother and father. The scene is set in heaven. Two vertical columns of clouds appear in the sky above the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Two gowned angels fly or hover above a family; the angels' wings may touch at the upper border of the design. The angel to the left faces right with its head down and looks at the figures below. The angel's right leg is bent slightly and the right foot is visible. The angel's right arm is bent with its hand resting on its left shoulder; the figure's left arm is not pictured.

Two gowned angels fly or hover above a family; the angels' wings may touch at the upper border of the design. The angel to the right faces left with its head down in profile and looks at the figures below. The angel's left leg is bent slightly and the left foot is visible. The left arm is bent with its hand resting on its right shoulder; the figure's right arm is not pictured.
A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family.

A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family. A male and female child kneel or crouch furthest left. The male kneels with his left knee on the ground and his right leg bent forward. He may wear short pants or breeches. The figure's arms are bent and wrap around the waist of a kneeling female with his hands together; the figures are embracing. The male figure's head is turned down and to the left; only the figure's short, curly hair and left eye(?) are visible. His head may rest on the female's right shoulder, and they may be kissing.

A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family. A female child kneels second from the left. She is seen from behind and faces away with her head turned slightly to the right. She is gowned and has long hair. Her left knee rests on the ground and her left foot is visible; her right leg is not clearly pictured. The figure's arms are bent and wrap around the neck and shoulders of the kneeling male; the figures are embracing and may be kissing.

A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family. A male with short curly hair stands third from the left; he is likely the father of the children to the left and right. The figure's left leg is bent slightly and his left foot raised on tiptoe. The figure wears a shirt, breeches, stockings, and shoes. The figure faces right with his head turned down; he embraces and kisses the female to the right. His right arm is bent and wraps around the back of the female figure to the right; his left hand holds the female's buttocks. There are shadows on the floor left and right of his right foot.

A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family. A gowned female stands fourth from the left; she is likely the mother of the children to the left and right. Her long hair is held loosely by a ribbon. The figure's left leg is bent slightly and her left foot raised on tiptoe. The figure faces left with her head turned up. She embraces and kisses the male to the left. Both arms are bent and wrap around the male's neck; her right hand rests on the male's right shoulder with the fingers spread.

A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family. A male child with short, curly hair stands fifth from the left; only his upper body is clearly visible. He wears a gown or shirt. The figure's arms are bent and wrap around the waist of the female child to the right; the figures are embracing and may be kissing.

A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family. A gowned female child with long hair stands sixth from the left. She is seen from behind and faces left. Her right leg is bent back slightly with her right foot raised on tiptoe. Her left arm is visible only to the elbow and is apparently raised at 45 degrees; she is likely embracing the male child to the left. Her head is turned up and she may kiss the male child. A shadow extends along the floor to the right.

A group of seven figures in the lower portion of the design represents a family. A male child with short, curly hair stands furthest right. He faces left with his mouth open. The child wears a shirt, breeches, stockings, and shoes. The figure's right leg is bent back with the right foot raised on tiptoe; he may be walking or running. His arms are raised at 135 degrees and extend to the left with the palms held vertically, fingers spread; he may be reaching towards his mother and father. A narrow shadow extends from his left foot along the floor.
The scene is set in heaven. Two vertical columns of clouds appear in the sky above the figures standing on what may be a floor of some sort.

desc.objtitle:
The Grave Personified A Characteristic Frontispiece,
Object 18

objnote.p: The white horizontal line, most visible at the central figure's ankles but extending across the entire design, was caused by the water color and its mount having been folded at an unknown time.

The design does not illustrate any specific passage in the poem, but would seem to represent a female personification of the grave, both the place and the poem. The design was not published in the 1808 edition, nor is it listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805. It might have been intended as the "characteristic Frontispiece" listed in the prospectus, but its horizontal format argues against that possibility. Inscribed, not by Blake, "The Grave Personified—Unfinished" on the cardboard mount below the design. The back of the mount is inscribed center left, "Not"—probably meaning not engraved. The back of the mount also bears a light pencil sketch picturing a figure in a posture similar to the woman in The Grave Personified , squatting and hunched over, with her(?) head between very prominent knees. This sketch may be by someone imitating Blake. The basic compositional format of *The Grave Personified* makes it a companion to A Destroying Deity: A Winged Figure Grasping Thunderbolts , a water color now in the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Butlin 778; preliminary sketch in the Yale Center for British Art).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The female personification of the grave sits or crouches on a stone plinth, platform, or throne in the center of the image. She is nude with her breasts exposed. Her hair is long and her eyes are raised. The figure faces forward with her legs bent and her feet touching. Her arms are raised horizontally with the palms turned down. She holds in each hand four stems from which dangle the round heads of (opium) poppies. Two butterfly-like or moth-like wings extend to the left and right; the wings are decorated with scalloped lines and large, circular designs like the "eyes" on peacock feathers. Two gowned figures sit to the left and right of the personification of the grave. The figure to the left faces left with its left leg drawn up. The figure to the right faces right with its right leg drawn up. Both figures are hunched over with their heads down. Long hair obscures their faces. Horizontal lines to the left and right of the central figure may represent steps or stairs. The scene may take place in a dark underground cave; shapes to the left and right of the central figure's feet and lower legs (perhaps the lower part of her throne) suggest plant or tree roots or branches, as do the forked forms above the hunched-over figures. Flames rise from the lower border of the desing; the dark forms along the left and right margins may be smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: The female personification of the grave sits or crouches on a stone platform or chair in the center of the image. The figure is nude with her breasts exposed. Her hair is long and her eyes are raised. The figure faces forward with her legs bent and her feet touching. Her arms are raised horizontally with the palms turned down, fingers slightly spread. She holds four poppies in each hand. Two butterfly-like or moth-like wings extend to the left and right; the wings are decorated with scalloped lines and large, circular designs like the "eyes" on peacock feathers.
The personification of the grave holds four stems in each hand from which dangle the round heads of (opium?) poppies.
The personification of the grave sits on a stone platform, plinth, or throne. Horizontal lines to the left and right of the central figure may represent steps or stairs.

The scene may take place in a dark underground cave; shapes to the left and right of the central figure's lower legs and feet (perhaps the lower part of her throne) suggest plant or tree roots or branches, as do the forked forms above the hunched-over figures. Flames rise above the lower margin; the dark forms along the left and right margins may be smoke.

Two gowned figures sit to the left and right of the personification of the grave. The figure to the left faces left with its left leg drawn up. The figure to the right faces right with its right leg drawn up. The figures both are hunched over with their heads down; long hair obscures their faces.

objtitle.title: A Man and Two Children beside an Open Grave
A Father and Two Children beside an Open Grave at Night by Lantern Light
A Burial Scene

objnote.p: The design does not illustrate any specific passage in the poem. The design was not published in the 1808 edition, nor is it listed in Cromek's first prospectus of Nov. 1805. Blake developed the design on the basis of his monochrome wash drawing of c. 1780-85, *Burial Scene* , now in the McGill University Library (Butlin 137).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned adult male and two gowned children kneel above an open grave. They may represent a family, although the adult's garb and the burial ceremony he seems to be performing suggest that he might be a priest. The adult male (furthest left) faces forward and slightly left. His left arm is bent and he holds an open book in his left hand. His eyes are cast down and he may be reading or looking into the grave. The figure's right arm is down at his side. The right hand is held open with the palm facing out towards the viewer and the fingers spread; he may be gesturing or pointing towards the open grave. To the right, a male child faces forward and slightly left; his head is down and he looks into the grave with an expression of grief or despair. The figure's arms are bent upward and he holds a portion of his gown up to his face, covering his mouth. To the right, a young female faces left with her head down slightly; she looks into the grave. Her arms are bent upward in front of her chest with the hands held together in prayer. A shovel and a lantern rest on the ground to the left of the adult male. A candle burns inside the lantern; the flame is barely visible and an aura of light radiates outward. Two leafy trees with distinct trunks and branches stand to the left of the figures, above the open grave. A third tree rises along the right border of the design; a leafy branch extends to the left above the figures' heads. Dark wash in the upper portion of the design suggests a night sky. A wind may be blowing from right to left, as indicated by the adult's hair, streaming out to the left, and the bending trees to the left.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned male kneels above an open grave. He may be the father of the two children to the right, although his garb and the burial ceremony he appears to be performing suggest that he might be a priest. He wears a gown and scarf. The figure faces forward and slightly left. His left arm is bent and he holds an open book in his left hand. His eyes are cast down and he may be reading or looking into the grave. The figure's right arm is down at his side. The right hand is held open with the palm facing out towards the viewer and the fingers spread; he may be gesturing or pointing towards the open grave.

A gowned child with short, curly hairpossibly malekneels on a mound above and to the right of an open grave. The child faces forward and slightly left; his head is down and he looks into the grave with an expression of grief or despair. The figure's arms are bent upward and he holds a portion of his gown up to his face, covering his mouth. He is likely the son of the male to the left.

A young gowned female with long hair kneels on a mound above and to the right of an open grave. The girl faces left with her head down slightly; she looks into the grave. Her arms are bent upward in front of her chest with the hands held together in prayer. She may be the daughter of the adult male to the left.
An open grave appears in the lower left portion of the design. A mound of earth stands to the right of the grave.
There may be a wind blowing from right to left, as indicated by the adult's hair, streaming out to the left, and the bend in the two trees on the left.
A shovel lies on the ground to the left of the adult male. The handle points to the left.

A lantern rests on the ground to the left of the adult male. A candle burns inside the lantern; the flame is barely visible and an aura of light radiates outward. The lantern casts a small shadow below; another shadow extends from the right knee of the kneeling adult male. A small loop or handle appears on top of the lantern.

Two leafy trees with distinct trunks and branches stand to the left of the figures, above the open grave. They may be cypress. A third tree, perhaps an oak, rises along the right border of the design; a leafy branch extends to the left above the figures' heads.
Dark wash in the upper portion of the design suggests a night sky.

desc.objtitle:
The Soul Exploring the Recesses of the Grave The Soul Exploring the Caverns of Death,
Object 20

objnote.p: The design does not illustrate any specific passage in the poem. A preliminary sketch is in the British Museum (Butlin 629); another possibly related drawing has been untraced since at least 1885 (Butlin 630). The design was etched and engraved by Louis Schiavonetti and published in the 1808 edition.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A cave or tomb of stone (the "Grave" referenced in the inscription on Schiavonetti's engraving of the design) dominates the lower portion of the design. A gowned female stands within the cave; the figure is likely a representation of the soul. The figure is seen from behind and faces away with her head turned to the right. Her hair is drawn back in a braided bun. Both feet are visible and her left foot is raised on tiptoe; she is probably walking away from the viewer. Her arms are bent and she holds a candle in her right hand; the candle is burning and the flame creates a halo of light. The figure casts a shadow below and to the left. She may look down and to the right toward a corpse of a male(?) figure. The corpse lies on the ground in a supine position, perhaps partly sunk into a shallow grave; the body is horizontal with the head to the right. The figure appears to be gowned or shrouded and wears a plumed helmet; he may be a knight or soldier. The figure's eyes are closed. A fire burns above the corpse. A male with short, curly hair stands above the cave. The figure is partly nude and wears short pants. Both legs are bent and are spread apart. His body faces forward with his head turned down to the left; his torso is twisted and bends to the left. The figure's arms are bent to the right with the palms held vertically. His eyes are cast down and he may be looking at the ground or the figure below; his mouth is open and his expression suggests fear or surprise. A series of distant mountains appears to the left and right of the male figure. A crescent moon appears in the sky between the male figure's legs. Two faint buildings, including a spire and perhaps a dome, rise below the mountain on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A cave or tomb of stone (the "Grave" in the inscription on Schiavonetti's engraving of the design) dominates the lower portion of the design. The body lying within the cave may be partly sunk into a shallow grave.

A gowned female stands in a cave in the lower portion of the design; the figure is likely a representation of the soul. The figure is seen from behind and faces away with her head turned to the right. Her hair is drawn back in a braided bun. Her left leg is bent back and crosses behind her right. Both feet are visible and her left foot is raised on tiptoe; she is probably walking away from the viewer. Both arms are bent and she holds a candle in her right hand; the candle is burning and the flame creates a halo of light. The figure casts a shadow below and to the left. She may look down and to the right toward a corpse.

The corpse of a male(?) figure lies supine in the lower portion of the design. The figure's body is horizontal with his head to the right, perhaps sunk partly into a shallow grave. The figure appears to be gowned or shrouded and wears a plumed helmet; he may be a knight or soldier. The figure's eyes are closed.
A fire burns above the corpse in the lower half of the design.

A male with short, curly hair stands in the upper portion of the design. The figure is partly nude and wears short pants. Both legs are bent and are spread apart. His body faces forward with his head turned down to the left; his torso is twisted and bends to the left. The figure's arms are bent to the right with the palms held vertically and the fingers spread. His eyes are cast down and he may be looking at the ground or the figure below; his mouth is open, with teeth visible, and his expression suggests fear or surprise.
A series of distant mountains appears to the left and right of the male figure.
A crescent moon appears in the sky between the male figure's legs.
Two buildings appear at the base of the mountain near the right border of the design. The building on the left is a spire; the one on the right has a rounded top and may be a dome.
